review_blob:
I have had this beer over three days. Day one there was a large presence of a bitterness like under ripened banana peel. This taste explains why I have had a few reviewers mentioned a chemical like presence. At least I presume this is what they were also picking up on. 

This beers high ABV has thinned the body and added a wonderful warming effect to the beer. Main characters included the already mentioned bitterness, lemon and a heavy amount of clove and coriander. 

But due either the role of oxygen in the bottle or the addition of the yeast this beer improved greatly. The aforementioned bitterness was minimal and no longer distracting me from the lemon, vanilla and bannana notes. The beer moved from a heavily sweet and spiced beer with a unique but slightly unpleasant bitterness to a wonderful balance of spices, fresh citrus and banana. 

If this is due to yeast I wish they would add more to the bottle or filter less out. I am pretty sure it is the yeast apposed to oxidation as my second tasting was identical to the first and the third was so much better. 

If you enjoyed this beer I would suggest you try La Buteuse by Le Trou du Diable. It matches a wonderful balance between sweetness and fruit, much like king heffy but with a bitter finish. Unlike this beer the first glass is as good as the last!

Cheers
beer_name: Howe Sound King Heffy Imperial Hefeweizen

review_blob:
Continuous sales on this ipa keep it fresh in Toronto and this IPA is a heavy hitter when fresh. Nickle Brooks new recipe is an amazing ipa that does not hurt the wallet. I wouldnt recommend this as someone first ipa as it may come across as too intensely bitter for some.  

Strong tropical fruit, lots of mango, pineapple, orange, orange peel, pine (low compared to the tropical fruit). Big Citra notes. Where this ipa may lack subtly it is exactly what I want out of an IPA. The malt comes through on the nose as it warms, when cold all I can get are the hops. 

The body the malt provides is heavy but not syrupy. There is plenty of resin left behind after each sip which leads to a long and enjoyable finish.

As someone who likes to pick up new beers for each session it is hard for me not to pick this one up over a new ipa that may be mediocre.
beer_name: Nickel Brook Headstock India Pale Ale

review_blob: Hops dominate the aroma as an ipa should but some malt does shine through. Some tropical fruit with bigger pine. Very nice looking brew with a deep red color to it. Malt is simple and really complements the hops. Very nice ipa. Flavor and odor are free of common flaws in the the style.

This beer does two things very well. The first would be its gimmic which is the cider wood chips. Gives this ipa a new dimension and a real cigar box feel. Although this flavor is quite dominant in this ipa the taste the cedar chips invoke really complement the hops in this Beer.

The malt is still present but its sweetness is more subdued in contrast to other dominant flavours. Although the malt might not be upfront it manages to bring that heavier body you get in an IIPA. 

If you are going to go this heavy handed with cedar chips this was the right style to try it out in. Really enjoyable.
beer_name: Flying Monkeys Matador Cedar Aged Double IPA

review_blob:
When I tried this beer I fell in love. But that was a long long time ago. I raved about the hop quality that made this brew unique. Looking at it now it probably needed to be aged. English hop character in a stout is very nice though and if I can ever get my hands on an english hopped black ipa this beer will at least give me hope for it working out. 

I am going to rate this from memory as it is no longer available and for what I would give it now instead of the 10/10 i would have given it before trying some of the worlds best beers.

God forbid you ever come across this beautiful bottle as it adds way too much to the price. Classy though. 

A wonderful mouth feel and a classic. Very simple but hits the nail in the head. The chocolate notes beat out other brews that have added chocolate. All the flavors you want in your porter and zero flaws. Find it in a can and its a steal. 

I really value complexity in a beer which this definitely does not have. I feel I may have over rated this but I am going to stick by it.

A very nice Imperial ipa at first. Has a nice heavier body, what youd expect from an iipa and the malt has a slight stickiness to it which I do appreciate. Low on pine and heavier on tropical fruit like I like my iipas. However as it warmed and god forbid I swirled it in the glass it was like summoning a garbage truck across my nose. Its a shame that such a nice ipa has such an upfront flaw on the nose.

Even after trying all the craft brews (most I have never rated here) Guiness is one of the few beers I thought was decent when my palate was horrible and still think of it as good. Guiness has put a lot of effort into encouraging bars to serve their drinks properly and to install specific nitro tap systems to get a fine texture one that I do appreciate. Guiness is a simple stout but there are no flaws and it has a freshness to its bitterness I cant ignore. 

I always lose hope to corrupt a none craft beer drinker into liking craft brews when they tell me what they drink followed by "but I cant handle guiness" as if it is the heaviest in weight and highest in abv. 

If guiness is too much flavor an ipa and god forbid an imperial anything will kill you!

Hits the style spot on. I had several of these from the LCBO despite the not so friendly price point. A great collaboration from two decent breweries. No flaws I could find. 

I have really enjoyed flying monkey products, they take risks and do produce some duds but they hit this one on the nose. If you like ASAs pick it up if you ever get the chance. Hopefully it did well enough to rise up again!
beer_name: Central City / Flying Monkeys Red on Red Imperial Red Ale

review_blob: Very nice beuatiful deep red brown. Fresh fruit taste up front and moves into caramel, vanilla, candied suger. Reminds me of candied apples at times. Slight wood dryness but not much, its subtle. But there is not too much subtly in this beer. Flavors are up front, sweet but not sticky sweet.

I had the worst bottle of Morsure from the LCBO. Its drain poor territory and you bet i am returning this bottle half full to the LCBO. There is a mild tiny flavour that tastes like maybe a drop of citra from grapefruit is hiding somewhere. This bottle is an APA at best and for a big beer drinker I dont feel like paying for an ipa that tastes like a lager but from other peopels reviews it is clearly this beer. 

Troue de diable makes amazing sours like Le Trou du Diable Bretteuse (Ft de Syrah) which is in my top 5. I have also had Shawinigan Handshake at the only Cafe (Amazing bar in Toronto) that tasted like an off brown ale with some hop caracter. This is strike 2 from one of my favorite breweries sending out of batch of crap.
beer_name: Le Trou du Diable la Morsure

review_blob:
Expensive beer but worth the price. My bottle from an LCBO in toronto is estimated at a couple months old, but the hops hold on hard.

Upfront tropical fruity hops are what your first introduced to on the nose but a light woodyness and cocoa come through as well. 

This wonderful cherry note on the pallet that may be part of the stout or may be a combination of the hops and the stouts flavours but its a very none candied fresh cherry. 

I am a fan of big Beers and the quality of all aspects of this beer are apparent.

Get leather and over-roasted coffee on the finish. Which is a great contrast to the fruity hop character at the start. At one point I thought black ipas would be my favorite style before getting heavily into multiple belgian styles. This Beer is a great way to remind me of its styles potential.

Poor with ease.

Aroma is of lemon and little vegetale and once it warms you get that wonderful belgian barnyard. 

Taste is floral, lemon, meringue with a warm mouth feel.

I get mild gingerbread and lemon on the finish 

Very nice.

Harviestoun Ola Dubh is very thin, warming, with no head. All signs of a high ABV. 

Taste leather, rauchbier smoke, cherry, cocoa, finishes with wood, and a certain sourness. NOT citrus, more tanic.

The Aroma steals the show with this beer as I can really enjoy the interplay between all the sweeter characteristics. Aroma is anis, rauchbier smokey, fleeting ginger, cherry and as it opens dark fruit, cocoa.

Although the finish will have fans of tanic notes and dry wood think they died and gone to heaven the wonderful play between the dark fruit, cocoa and smokiness that makes the aroma so wonderful is short lived and lost in the finish. 

This would be a perfect gift for Christmas for a Beer loving friend, as it is a real winter warmer and too dear to not be drank not on a special occasion.

Aroma improves as this beer opens up. I smell perfume a bit of alcohol cheese light caramel and light fruit. Beer is a foggy burnt yellow.

Appearance: Foam lingers, although it was chilled it easily generated a two inch head in my wine glass. Foam lingers around for 15 min and settles to the edges of the glass with a thin island of foam in the center of the glass that remains throughout your drinking experience. 

Taste: This triple is bitter and dry. Light fruit is present but I wouldnt describe this beer as sweet. There is a definite basement mustiness that works well with sence of a honey comb that could also be described as soap. vAs a note the fruitness really comes out on the palette when/if you burp.

cheese, mild fungi, basement and 

Palate: Thin and dry. Alcohol is warming to the palate and beyond. 

When I think of triples I tend to lean towards a stronger fruit profile along with the funk this beer is able to present to us. That being said this is a lovely beer that is perfect when I am looking for something dry and bitter. A pleasant change to my usual preferences.

Aroma Lightly roasted malt, vanilla, apple, caramel, bright lemon, mild wood

Appearance: hazy, cider brown, decent lacing. One centimeter of head that quickly disperses. 

Taste: vanilla, cider, strawberry, lime, woody dry and juicey. This beer is complex to have stages of varying dryness to juiceyness throughout the finish. 

Palate: Thin and fruity that dries on the finish (some fruitiness does stick around for a wonderful finish.)

Very nice beer, meets the style well. Very well balanced and most importantly complex enough that it takes more than one sitting to really get to know. Thank you LCBO for releasing this. I am so found of sours but often access to quality sours is difficult. 

I gave it a 8 over all but its a 95 to 100 for the style in my opinion. To determine those extra five points I would need to have this wonderful sour with another respected of the style to truly know.
